articles.name: Methods to Set-up Interviews
articles.title: Methods to Set-up Interviews
articles.body:
Recruiters can schedule an interview between interviewers and candidates. There are two ways in which you can set up interviews:

  • Quick Pad: Recruiters can create a quick pad by providing the candidate's email address. The link for a quick pad is immediately generated, and the recruiter can share this link with the interviewer and the candidate in their preferred mode. HackerRank does not send any notifications for quick pads. The recruiter is responsible for keeping all the participants informed about the scheduled time and providing them with the generated links. 
  • Scheduled Interview: You can schedule an interview between the candidate and the interviewers. HackerRank sends out email notifications to the candidates and the interviewers specifying the details such as the link to the interview, the date, and the time. The interviewers might also receive additional details such as the phone number of the candidate, additional notes, and the candidate's resume if specified by the recruiter.
    Refer to the Scheduling an Interview topic for more information.

articles.name: Approximate Solution Type Question
articles.title: Approximate Solution Type Question
articles.body:
Approximate Solution questions are basically coding questions. The solutions to these problems tend to find approximate solutions to optimization problems. These questions are particularly useful for domains of software development where there is no single correct answer, such as image processing or computer vision.

Example

You can create a custom checker to score these questions because these questions have more than one acceptable answer. For example, The list of 5 prime numbers is less than 100. There are 25 prime numbers less than 100. So, candidates can list any combination of 5 prime numbers from the list of 25 prime numbers, and they will all be correct answers. In the custom checker, you can also choose to give a partial score to a candidate who lists 3 prime and 2 composite numbers. The candidate, in this case, will receive 3 points for the question if the total score for this question is 5 points.

Therefore, unlike the binary pass and fail strategy that works well for coding questions, a custom checker can use the logic you determine and give partial credit to make more optimum scoring decisions.

Refer to the following topics for more information:

  1. Creating an Approximate Solution Type Question
  2. Scoring an Approximate Solution Type Question
  3. Creating a Custom Checker

articles.name: Setting up the Event Microsite
articles.title: Setting up the Event Microsite
articles.body:
Overview

After setting up your event, you can create your microsite with your preferences. This is shown as the Publish Microsite task on the Event home page.

The Microsite editing feature comprises of three key sections:

Content

This is the section in which you can modify the content of your microsite. You have the flexibility to modify microsite sections by hiding, reordering, and adding new sections. After you have configured it, you can edit the content within these sections.

This flexibility allows you to tailor your microsite for various types of engagements, such as coding challenges, physical meetups, virtual summits, and so on.

You can edit or add the categories as per your requirements:

 

Styling

 This is the section in which you can choose the microsite layout and customize label colors according to your preferences.

 

Registration

In this section, you can define the eligibility criteria for default fields, remove fields that are not required, introduce new custom fields, and define eligibility criteria for them. Setting eligibility criteria is an essential step as it ensures the automatic segregation of candidates into the eligible and non-eligible buckets automatically, without any user intervention. All the eligible candidates will get invited to the event once you publish your challenge.

Publish the Microsite

After you have set up the microsite based on your requirements, publish the microsite.

Important: You will not be able to modify the Eligibility Criteria, Participation type, and registration form fields once you have published the microsite. 

The microsite is published. You can preview how the microsite looks or just copy the link and share it with your marketing team to start marketing your event.

articles.name: Creating Workflows in Engage
articles.title: Creating Workflows in Engage
articles.body:
Overview

HackerRank enables you to run candidate nurture campaigns using a sequence of ready-made branded emails. This is referred to as candidate workflow.

You can upload a pre-existing or passive candidate list from any source (with name and email) and invite them through email sequences to register for an event till the last day of event registration. You can also upload a shortlisted pool of candidates from the registered list and engage with candidates through email sequences post-registration to ensure a good candidate turnout for your event.

Launch the Workflows Wizard

You can invite candidates to events by creating a sequence of emails.

    1. After you create an Event, from the Create Event wizard, click Goto Workflow under Invite candidates or click on the Event card on the Engage home page.
    2. The Workflow wizard is displayed. From here, you can invite candidates and create a workflow to send out the emails for the event. The emails are based on the pre-registration and post-registration stages of the event.

      Note: Once you start the Workflow, you will not be able to add emails or edit the existing ones. The Workflows become active once you start them and you cannot change them.

Initiate Workflows for Pre-Registration and Post Registration of Events

You can upload a pre-existing or passive candidate list from any source (with name and email) and invite them through email sequences to register for an event till the last day of event registration. You can also upload a shortlisted pool of candidates from the registered list and engage with candidates through email sequences post-registration.

Invite Candidates to Engage

  1. A Workflow consists of four default emails for the pre-registration and post-registration stages. You can customize these emails by clicking the edit icon.
  2. You can also add emails by clicking Add Email.
  3. Once you have finalized your emails, you can import candidates you want to invite for the Event by clicking the add user icon .
  4. You need to upload the list of candidates in a CSV format. The candidates' list is imported and displays the valid records.
  5. Click Import. The candidates are imported.
  6. You can start the workflow only after you have published your microsite.
  7. Click Start to start the Workflow.
  8. A prompt message is displayed to inform you that once you start the Workflow, you will not be able to edit the Workflow.
  9. Click Start. The Workflow is initiated and becomes active.
  10. From this point onwards, the candidates uploaded to the Workflow will start receiving emails. You can also add more users to the Workflow over time (this functionality is not disabled upon starting a Workflow).

Engage Candidates on Pre-Registration

  1. Once you activate a Workflow, the emails are sent automatically in a sequence to the candidates you have selected. You need not schedule these emails. These candidates will be able to register on the Microsite.
  2. You can download the candidates' list who have registered by clicking the download icon on the Workflows page against the Invite Candidates Workflow.
  3. You can then see that the candidate's value in the CSV file (after you download) changes from FALSE to TRUE.

Engage Candidates on Post-Registration

  1. After the candidates register, and you have shortlisted the candidates based on your eligibility criteria (for example, Region=US, Gender=Female, and so on), upload the candidate list.
  2. Now click Start to start the Workflow for post-registration. The Post Registration Workflow is now Active.
  3. Accordingly, the sequence of emails is sent to the candidates whom you shortlist, and you can keep them engaged till the day of the event.
